questions.question: What is the main difference between a goal and an intention?
options: Goals are easier to achieve than intentions
Intentions are internal commitments about who you want to become, while goals are external targets
Goals are short-term and intentions are long-term
There is no meaningful difference between them
questions.explanation: An intention is an internal commitment about how you want to feel and who you want to become, while a goal is an external target to achieve.
questions.reviewContent: Intentions focus on your inner transformation and values, creating a deeper foundation for lasting change than goals alone.

questions.question: Drinking a glass of water before meals can help with appetite regulation and digestion.
questions.explanation: Water before meals aids digestion and can help you feel fuller, supporting natural portion control.
questions.reviewContent: Water supports metabolism, appetite regulation, and digestion. Drinking before meals is especially beneficial.

questions.question: What is the recommended approach to body awareness?
options: Be harshly critical to motivate change
Ignore body signals and follow strict rules
Observe without judgment and with gentle curiosity
Only pay attention when something feels wrong
questions.explanation: Body awareness means observing your signals without judgment, with gentle curiosity and compassion.
questions.reviewContent: Honest self-assessment doesn't mean harsh criticism. It means gentle, non-judgmental observation of your patterns.

questions.question: According to environment design principles, how should you arrange healthy foods in your kitchen?
options: Hide them so you don't eat them too fast
Place them at eye level and in visible locations
Store them only in the pantry
questions.explanation: Making healthy foods visible and accessible—at eye level in the refrigerator, for example—makes healthy choices easier.
questions.reviewContent: Environment design means making healthy choices visible and accessible while removing or hiding temptations.

questions.question: You need everyone in your life to approve of and support your wellness journey for it to succeed.
questions.explanation: You don't need everyone's approval. Find your tribe—the people who support and celebrate your growth.
questions.reviewContent: Not everyone will understand your journey. Focus on finding supportive people rather than seeking universal approval.

questions.question: What is the general baseline recommendation for daily water intake?
questions.explanation: The general baseline is about 8 glasses (64 ounces) per day, with adjustments for activity level and climate.
questions.reviewContent: Aim for 8 glasses daily as a baseline. Increase when active, in warm weather, or consuming caffeine.

questions.question: Reflect on your personal 'why' for this wellness journey. What deeper meaning drives your commitment?
questions.explanation: Reflection questions help deepen your personal connection to the material.

questions.question: The 70/30 harmony principle suggests that wellness results come from:
questions.explanation: The 70/30 principle indicates that approximately 70% of wellness results come from nutrition, while 30% comes from physical activity.
questions.reviewContent: While both matter, what you eat has a greater impact on body composition. You can't out-exercise a poor diet.

questions.question: Soluble fiber dissolves in water and helps regulate blood sugar levels.
questions.explanation: Soluble fiber dissolves in water, forming a gel-like substance that helps regulate blood sugar and lower cholesterol.
questions.reviewContent: Soluble fiber (in oats, beans, apples) helps blood sugar and cholesterol. Insoluble fiber (in vegetables, whole grains) aids digestion.

questions.question: Which of the following is a complete plant-based protein source?
questions.explanation: Quinoa is one of the few plant sources that contains all essential amino acids, making it a complete protein.
questions.reviewContent: Protein is essential at every meal. Both animal (eggs, fish, chicken) and plant sources (legumes, quinoa, tofu) are valuable.

questions.question: Which of these foods has a LOW glycemic index?
questions.explanation: Steel-cut oats have a low glycemic index, meaning they raise blood sugar slowly and steadily.
questions.reviewContent: Low GI foods (most vegetables, beans, apples, steel-cut oats) provide sustained energy. High GI foods spike blood sugar.

questions.question: All dietary fats are harmful and should be avoided for optimal health.
questions.explanation: Healthy fats (from olive oil, avocados, nuts, fatty fish) are essential for brain function, hormone production, and nutrient absorption.
questions.reviewContent: Your body needs healthy fats for hormones, brain function, and absorbing vitamins. Choose unsaturated fats over saturated ones.

questions.question: Which type of fat should be completely avoided?
questions.explanation: Trans fats (partially hydrogenated oils) should be avoided entirely as they have no health benefits and increase disease risk.
questions.reviewContent: Trans fats are the only fats to avoid entirely. Saturated fats should be limited, while unsaturated fats are beneficial.

questions.question: What is the recommended daily fiber intake?
questions.explanation: The recommended daily fiber intake is 25-30 grams, though most people only consume about 15 grams.
questions.reviewContent: Aim for 25-30 grams of fiber daily. Increase gradually and drink more water as you add fiber to your diet.

questions.question: Name three protein sources (animal or plant-based) that you would like to include more often in your meals.
questions.explanation: Reflection prompts help you connect the material to your personal life.

questions.question: How many times should you aim to chew each bite of food?
questions.explanation: Chewing each bite approximately 30 times allows food to break down properly and triggers satiety signals.
questions.reviewContent: Chewing 30 times per bite releases digestive enzymes, improves nutrient absorption, and helps you feel satisfied sooner.

questions.question: Digestion begins in the stomach, not the mouth.
questions.explanation: Digestion actually begins in the mouth, where saliva contains enzymes that start breaking down food.
questions.reviewContent: Digestion begins in the mouth with saliva enzymes. Proper chewing is the first step of good digestion.

questions.question: Using your hand as a portion guide, what represents an appropriate protein serving?
questions.explanation: Your palm (thickness and size) represents an appropriate protein portion for one meal.
questions.reviewContent: Hand guides: Palm = protein, cupped handful = carbs, thumb = fats, two cupped handfuls = vegetables.

questions.question: Which food allows you to eat the MOST volume for the same number of calories?
questions.explanation: Broccoli has very low calorie density—you can eat 1000g for 536 calories, compared to only 100g of chips.
questions.reviewContent: Low-calorie-density foods (vegetables, fruits) fill your stomach with fewer calories and more nutrients.

questions.question: Empty calories provide energy but little to no nutritional value.
questions.explanation: Empty calories (from sodas, candy, refined foods) provide energy without beneficial nutrients like vitamins and minerals.
questions.reviewContent: Focus on nutrient-dense foods (vegetables, fruits, whole grains, lean proteins) rather than empty calories.

questions.question: Which of these eating environment changes supports mindful eating?
options: Eating while watching TV to relax
Eliminating screens and sitting at a table
Eating directly from packages to save dishes
questions.explanation: Eliminating distractions and sitting at a table helps you eat mindfully and recognize satiety signals.
questions.reviewContent: Create a mindful eating space: sit at a table, use real plates, eliminate screens, and take at least 15 minutes per meal.

questions.question: According to the plate method, how much of your plate should be filled with non-starchy vegetables?
questions.explanation: The plate method suggests filling half your plate with non-starchy vegetables.
questions.reviewContent: Plate method: half vegetables, quarter protein, quarter carbs, plus a small amount of healthy fat.

questions.question: Describe what a mindful meal looks and feels like for you. What changes would make your eating experience more nourishing?
questions.explanation: Reflection helps you envision and commit to positive changes.

questions.question: A balanced breakfast should include which three components?
options: Protein, complex carbohydrates, and healthy fat
questions.explanation: A balanced breakfast includes protein (for satiety), complex carbohydrates (for energy), and healthy fat (for satisfaction).
questions.reviewContent: The balanced breakfast formula: protein (eggs, yogurt) + complex carbs (oats, whole grain) + healthy fat (avocado, nuts).

questions.question: The afternoon energy slump is often caused by eating too much protein at lunch.
questions.explanation: The afternoon slump is usually caused by too many simple carbohydrates, not protein. Protein helps prevent energy crashes.
questions.reviewContent: A protein-rich lunch with vegetables prevents afternoon crashes. Avoid simple carbs that spike and crash blood sugar.

questions.question: How long before bedtime should you ideally finish eating dinner?
questions.explanation: Eating 2-3 hours before bed allows time for digestion and promotes better sleep quality.
questions.reviewContent: Finish dinner at least 2-3 hours before bed. Keep portions moderate and avoid heavy, rich foods at night.

questions.question: Drinking one regular soda daily for a year can result in approximately how much weight gain?
questions.explanation: One regular soda daily adds approximately 140-170 calories, which can result in about 15 pounds of weight gain per year.
questions.reviewContent: Liquid calories add up quickly without satisfying hunger. Swap sweetened beverages for water, tea, or sparkling water.

questions.question: Green tea contains catechins that may help boost metabolism.
questions.explanation: Green tea contains catechins, compounds that research suggests may help boost metabolism.
questions.reviewContent: Teas offer benefits without calories. Green tea has catechins for metabolism, while herbal teas support various health goals.

questions.question: What is the recommended approach to changing unhealthy eating habits?
options: Focus on swapping unhealthy choices for healthier alternatives
questions.explanation: The swap strategy focuses on replacing unhealthy choices with satisfying healthy alternatives rather than just eliminating foods.
questions.reviewContent: Swap rather than eliminate: chips → roasted chickpeas, soda → sparkling water, candy → fresh fruit with dark chocolate.

questions.question: The 80/20 approach means:
options: Make nourishing choices 80% of the time, allow flexibility 20%
questions.explanation: The 80/20 approach means making nourishing choices 80% of the time while allowing 20% flexibility for special occasions and treats.
questions.reviewContent: The 80/20 approach creates sustainable balance. Perfection isn't required—consistent good choices are what matter.

questions.question: What are three practical changes you could make to improve your lunch choices this week?
questions.explanation: Reflection helps you apply concepts to your specific situation.

questions.question: Approximately how many calories does moderate-paced walking burn per hour?
questions.explanation: Walking at a moderate pace burns approximately 290 calories per hour while providing numerous other benefits.
questions.reviewContent: Walking is accessible, free, and burns about 290 calories per hour. Start with 5 minutes and build gradually.

questions.question: Intense exercise immediately after eating is the best way to aid digestion.
questions.explanation: Gentle movement (like a casual walk) aids digestion, but intense exercise can actually disrupt the digestive process.
questions.reviewContent: Post-meal movement should be gentle: a casual walk, light stretching, or standing activities. Avoid intense exercise.

questions.question: Research shows that walking after a meal helps:
options: Has no effect on blood sugar
Only affects cholesterol, not blood sugar
questions.explanation: Studies show that a 15-minute walk after a meal can significantly reduce blood sugar spikes compared to remaining sedentary.
questions.reviewContent: A 15-minute walk after meals significantly reduces blood sugar spikes. This is especially important after carb-rich meals.

questions.question: The 5-5-5 approach to building movement means:
options: Exercise 5 times per week for 5 weeks, then 5 months
Do 5 exercises, 5 times each, for 5 minutes
Start with 5 minutes, add 5 minutes each week
Exercise at 5am, 5pm, and 5 days per week
questions.explanation: The 5-5-5 approach means starting with just 5 minutes of movement and adding 5 minutes each week until you reach your goal.
questions.reviewContent: Start with 5 minutes (so easy you can't say no), add 5 minutes each week. Build gradually for sustainable habits.

questions.question: The best form of movement is the one you enjoy and will actually do consistently.
questions.explanation: Sustainability comes from enjoyment. Any movement you'll do consistently is better than 'perfect' exercise you'll skip.
questions.reviewContent: The best movement is what you enjoy. Variety prevents boredom and works different muscles. Find your joy.

questions.question: After age 30, how much muscle mass can we lose per decade without strength training?
questions.explanation: Without strength training, we can lose 3-8% of muscle mass per decade after age 30, affecting metabolism and function.
questions.reviewContent: Strength training (body flow) maintains muscle mass (we lose 3-8% per decade after 30) and boosts metabolism.

questions.question: Rest days should be completely avoided to maximize fitness results.
questions.explanation: Rest days (1-2 per week) are essential for recovery. Your body builds strength during rest, not just during exercise.
questions.reviewContent: Include 1-2 rest days weekly for recovery. Rest days can still include gentle walking or stretching.

questions.question: What types of movement bring you joy? What new activities would you like to try?
questions.explanation: Reflection helps you connect movement to personal enjoyment.

questions.question: Which phrase is an example of empowering language?
options: 'I choose to nourish my body with movement'
questions.explanation: 'I choose to' is empowering language that reflects personal agency, rather than obligation or restriction.
questions.reviewContent: Transform: 'I have to' → 'I choose to', 'I can't' → 'I'm choosing not to', 'I should' → 'I want to'

questions.question: Discipline is best understood as punishment for past failures.
questions.explanation: Discipline is not punishment—it's an act of self-love and keeping promises to yourself.
questions.reviewContent: Discipline is self-love in action: keeping promises to yourself and choosing long-term joy over short-term pleasure.

questions.question: What is the key difference between an excuse and an explanation?
options: An excuse prevents action, while an explanation leads to problem-solving
They are essentially the same thing
Explanations are always valid, excuses never are
questions.explanation: An excuse stops action ('I can't because...'), while an explanation leads to solutions ('This is challenging, so I'll...').
questions.reviewContent: Transform excuses into explanations with solutions. 'I don't have time' becomes 'My schedule is busy, so I'll find two 10-minute windows.'

questions.question: What is the recommended way to respond to your inner critic?
options: Acknowledge it, thank it, and update it with compassion
questions.explanation: The inner critic means well but uses outdated strategies. Acknowledge it, thank it for trying to protect you, and update it with new information.
questions.reviewContent: Work with your inner critic: 'I hear you, thank you for trying to protect me, but I've grown and can handle this now.'

questions.question: Failure should be viewed as information and a stepping stone, not as a permanent roadblock.
questions.explanation: Every 'failure' provides information about what doesn't work, proof that you're trying, and an opportunity to grow.
questions.reviewContent: Failure is part of success, not the opposite of it. It provides information, proves you're trying, and creates opportunity for adjustment.

questions.question: Why should you be careful with 'I am' statements?
options: What follows 'I am' shapes your identity
questions.explanation: 'I am' statements shape your identity. 'I am building my fitness' is much more empowering than 'I am bad at exercise.'
questions.reviewContent: 'I am' statements are powerful: 'I am bad at exercise' reinforces limitation. 'I am building my fitness' creates possibility.

questions.question: How do discipline and consistency differ?
options: Discipline is doing what needs to be done; consistency is showing up regularly allowing for imperfection
Discipline is for beginners; consistency is advanced
questions.explanation: Discipline gets you through tough moments; consistency means showing up regularly while allowing for human imperfection.
questions.reviewContent: Discipline: doing what's needed even when you don't feel like it. Consistency: showing up regularly, allowing for imperfection.

questions.question: Write a brief personal wellness declaration—a statement of who you are becoming and how you choose to live.
questions.explanation: Your wellness declaration is your personal commitment to your journey.

keyPoints: Animal and plant sources both valuable
Low GI foods provide sustained energy
Best movement is what you enjoy
